newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia takes first steps in gold liberalisation.
newsitem.headline: Russia takes first steps in gold liberalisation.

text.p: A commission headed by Russian First Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly Chubais and charged with liberalising the gold market approved a resolution on direct gold sales to individuals, Interfax news agency said Thursday.

Interfax quoted Viktor Tarakanovsky, chairman of the Gold Prospectors' Union, as saying a document "On the sale of precious metals to individuals" was approved late on Wednesday, and would be passed to the government for signing in seven days.
The report said the commission also approved a resolution on the necessity of "significantly simplifying the procedure for exporting precious metals from Russia".

But a document "On precious metals trading" was sent back for further work as it conflicted with a clause in Russia's Criminal Code giving five years imprisonment for precious metals sales which exclude the government, Tarakanovsky said.
Interfax quoted an unnamed source as saying the draft resolution would allow gold producers to sell gold freely if the government failed to pay for it within 30 days.
Last month Chubais announced that Russia's gold market needed radical changes, and that a working group was considering concrete proposals to liberalise the heavily-centralised market.

Officials had said that commercial banks were likely to play a much more important role in pre-financing gold production, with analysts saying that in exchange they could be given the right to export gold.
The authoritative business daily Kommersant quoted First Deputy Prime Minister Boris Nemtsov as saying that commercial banks should indeed have the right to export.
"Let commercial banks export as much gold as they like," he was quoted as saying.
Where the liberalisation of the gold market left the even more secretive world of platinum group metals remained unclear.

Russian exports of the vital hard currency earners platinum and palladium have been held up for months because a decree outlining export quotas of platinum group metals had not been signed by the government.
But an official at export agency Almazjuvelirexport said on Wednesday that he understood the decree had finally been signed.
